awd_titl_txt: The contributions of the environment and social interaction to language emergence
awd_abstract_narration:
This award was provided as part of NSF's Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships (SPRF) program. The goal of the SPRF program is to prepare promising, early career doctoral-level scientists for scientific careers in academia, industry or private sector, and government. SPRF awards involve two years of training under the sponsorship of established scientists and encourage Postdoctoral Fellows to perform independent research. NSF seeks to promote the participation of scientists from all segments of the scientific community, including those from underrepresented groups, in its research programs and activities; the postdoctoral period is considered to be an important level of professional development in attaining this goal. Each Postdoctoral Fellow must address important scientific questions that advance their respective disciplinary fields. Under the sponsorship of Dr. Mahesh Srinivasan at University of California Berkeley, and in collaboration with Dr. Terra Edwards at University of Chicago, this postdoctoral fellowship award supports an early career scientist investigating the roles of the body and social interaction in language emergence. Over the last few decades, we have learned about the origins of language through stunning naturalistic observations of children who lack exposure to conventional language models. Such situations often arise within the deaf population, where the majority of deaf children do not have access to a perceptible linguistic system, like a sign language. Despite these impoverished linguistic environments, children develop systematic gestural systems, known as “homesign,” to communicate. These examples of language emergence and change have been attributed to the nature of children’s own learning mechanisms. But there is also a social and interactional dimension that has not been systematically explored within the field of language emergence, particularly with respect to how children and their parents jointly establish reference and the role of parents’ social and non-linguistic responses in the development of homesign systems. 

The proposed research addresses the emergence of language among DeafBlind children who vary in their access to language input and environments, and compares this situation with that of homesigners and deaf native signers. Although there is a new emerging protactile sign language (a sign language that is communicate within the tactile channel) within a community of DeafBlind adults in the US, this new language has not yet been acquired by children, and only some DeafBlind children have the opportunity to learn this language. Studying DeafBlind, homesigning, and deaf native signing children will allow us to ask the following theoretical questions: 1) When there is a large gap between a hearing, sighted parent and child’s perceptual experiences of the world, how do they converge on mutual understanding and establish common ground to communicate? How do signing, homesigning, and DeafBlind children compare in the development of their communication systems? 2) When DeafBlind children receive protactile language input, how do they change the language based on their learning and perceptual needs? 3) What kinds of assumption do homesigning and DeafBlind children exhibit about language and meaning? This research program will involve mixed methods, including psycholinguistic experiments, language elicitation tasks, coding of language and social interactions, and surveys. This research will also inform us whether parents’ social and non-linguistic cues are essential for driving the development of communication systems and demonstrate how children change their language input to make it easier to process and learn. It is an incredibly rare opportunity to find a cohort of DeafBlind children at a such a young age, and there is no previous work on children’s acquisition of protactile language. DeafBlind children, in particular, are greatly impacted during this unprecedented time of social distancing and isolation. This work will inform teachers and early intervention practitioners on how to best provide social and linguistic input for DeafBlind children.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The current research investigates how words and their meanings are shaped by concepts, interaction, and community-specific conventions in situations of language creation and emergence. I investigate these questions with a particular focus on lexical semantics and meta-linguistic functions in child-adult interactions within homesign and protactile language. In the first study, I document the first known case of DeafBlind children learning conventionalized protactile language and communication practices from DeafBlind adults, a process that contributes to the emergence of protactile language in the US. In the second study, I explore the roles of intuitive conceptual structure and social interaction in shaping lexical semantics in deaf children who spontaneously generate their own gesture systems at home and do not have input to a conventional sign language (homesign). 

The first study addresses how DeafBlind children and adults coordinate and jointly contribute to language emergence. Over the past decade, a subset of DeafBlind adults in the United States began communicating directly with one another via reciprocal, tactile channels--a practice known as protactile. Prior research has shown that these practices are leading to new grammatical patterns at the sub-lexical level and that a new grammatical system for coordinating intersubjective engagement (e.g. a deictic system) is emerging. However, these systems had never been acquired by DeafBlind children and there have been no documented cases of DeafBlind adult to DeafBlind child transmission. Therefore, there is much to learn about the contribution of DeafBlind children to the emergence of protactile language. 

We introduced a cohort of DeafBlind children to skilled DeafBlind protactile signers. More specifically, we studied a linguistic structure, called protactile tappings. Similar to indexical pointing or head-nodding in spoken and signed languages, these protactile taps have demonstrative and backchanneling functions. They also play a significant role in the turn-taking structure of protactile language. During these interactions, the adult re-purposes protactile taps by producing meta-channel taps to direct them to the conventional articulators for protactile language (e.g., the hands, but not the mouth, are appropriate for communication). The meta-channel function predominates relative to demonstrative functions in the adult’s input. In the presence of child learners, this new linguistic category emerged within protactile taps. This study documented how child language learners contribute to protactile language emergence as adult speakers adjust their language to accommodate the child’s mind. 

Similar to how the Deafblind children and adults are learning how to converge and align their attention to their environments, deaf homesigners and hearing caregivers also attempt to communicate despite not having a shared linguistic system. The second study addresses the concepts that homesigners bring to communication and the specific social context that facilitates that process by examining the role of the caregivers’ understanding of the child. In particular, we focus on polysemy – in which a word has multiple meanings (e.g., the English word, chicken has meat and animal senses). Building on previous work on homesign, we first analyze the meanings of the child’s gestures in a fine-grained way by referencing WordNet, a large lexical database of English, that labels the semantic relations among words. Secondly, we code the caregivers’ pragmatic and non-linguistic feedback in response to the child’s gestures. Previous research has primarily focused on parents’ linguistic or gestural input, but we go beyond this level of analysis by analyzing the adults’ non-linguistic responses– non-linguistic responses–tactile, visual, and action-based behaviors–that could indicate their comprehension of the child’s gestures. 

In the process, we unearthed many more new meaning extensions. The homesigners spontaneously use the same gesture form, such as flapping B hand movements, to denote flying, airplane, bird, or butterfly. These gestures are mirrored by conventional patterns of polysemy in spoken and signed languages. In contrast, the caregivers rarely used gestures with multiple meanings, and in one case in which they did, they used with a smaller range of meanings than the children. However, a possible precondition for this emergence is having an interlocutor who was attempting to understand them. The caregivers responded to the child appropriately most of the time. The children’s lexical creativity was unlikely to be learned from their caregiver, as it was not in their input, however social interaction and convergence on the same objects matter. 

This research highlights the tight coherence across interactional and linguistic development, contributing to ongoing dialogues in the fields of linguistics, anthropology, and psychology. It is an incredibly rare opportunity to find a cohort of DeafBlind children, and to be able to compare them with deaf children with various linguistic experiences. This research has also provided additional scientific training for DeafBlind scientists and collaborators, and as part of our community work, we have disseminated these research findings with families, who have participated in the study and now use many protactile words and grammatical structures in their daily interactions with their DeafBlind children.
